newsitem.title: INDIA: India's exports dip in first quarter of 1997/98.
newsitem.headline: India's exports dip in first quarter of 1997/98.

text.p: India's exports dipped in the April-June quarter because of a strong rupee, depressed global markets and poor infrastructure, analysts said on Friday.
The Commerce Ministry reported that exports fell by 0.95 percent to $8.13 billion in the first quarter of fiscal 1997/98 (April-March) from $8.21 billion a year earlier.
"It is definitely a cause for worry," said Bidisha Ganguly, an economist with securities firm W.I. Carr.
Ganguly said the government had to give a "big push" to spur exports.
Exports in June rose by a niggardly 2.53 percent to $2.66 billion from $2.59 billion in June 1996.
Analysts said exports of gems, jewellery and leather goods, some of India's principal items, had been plagued by internal problems.
"Corporates will have to rethink their strategy and build up exports," V. Raghuraman, secretary general of Associated Chambers of Commerce (Assocham), told Reuters.
"With the appreciation of the rupee (against the dollar) and depreciation of the currency in some of the surrounding countries there will be some anxieties among the exporters," Raghuraman said.
Exporters also complain that the rupee, which has been trading in the range of 35.70-35.90 to the dollar for the past year, is overvalued and affecting competitiveness in a depressed global market.
The Reserve Bank of India had to intervene regularly to stop the rupee from appreciating as foreign investors bought rupees with dollars.
Imports in April-June increased by 4.22 percent to $9.53 billion from $9.15 billion in the same period a year earlier.
Oil imports dropped 9.89 percent to $2.06 billion from $2.28 billion in the corresponding period a year ago.
"Domestic oil production is increasing," Ganguly said, when asked for reasons for the fall in oil imports.
India's crude oil output during April-June 1997 rose to 8.40 million tonnes from 8.17 million tonnes in the same period in 1996, a Petroleum Ministry document obtained by Reuters on Thursday said.
Non-oil imports grew 8.42 percent to $7.47 billion in April-June 1997 from $6.86 in the same period in 1996, the Commerce Ministry said.
"This is positive and shows signs of a revival of industrial growth," Raghuraman said.
Industrial output rose 9.8 percent in April compared with 8.1 percent in same month in 1996.
"Infrastructure bottlenecks continue to a major problem affecting industrial growth. This also affects imports," Raghuraman said.

India, which launched an economic liberalisation programme in 1991, estimates it needs some $150 billion in investment over five years to build infrastructure facilties like power plants, ports, roads and telecommunications.
